loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael sells secondhand clothes in Nakuru town and also has a mining business. He has applied for his third loan from KADET LTD after paying his previous loan in a timely manner. He intends to buy fabric materials used in making clothes for his business with the loan amount.

He hopes to open a boutique in Nakuru in the near future.

loans.use: to buy materials for his clothing business.

loans.name: Pascual

texts.en: Pascual is a married man from the town of CPG, Bohol. He has been engaged in a motorcycle transport business for more than 10 years now. This is the source of his income. Habal-habal, a local name for motorcycle transportation, is a common way of transporting passengers especially in mountainous areas inaccessible to cars and four wheel vehicles. Pascual is asking for a loan to buy spare parts for his motorcycle like wheels, tires, chain, oil, nuts, and bolts. Through this, he will be able to maintain the good working condition of his motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy spare motorcycle parts like wheels, tires, chains, oil, nuts, and bolts.

loans.name: Lasha

texts.en:
Lasha is 23 years old. He lives in Sartichala village, Gardabani district with his 23-year-old wife and 2-year-old daughter. Lasha requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Lasha and his wife are working at private companies to earn small monthly salaries.  Lasha is working as a security guard and his wife is an operator at the local market. Family total income is rarely enough to cover their monthly food expenses.   

Lasha requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Lasha has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions a provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With his credit Lasha will purchase a milk cow. The cow will be milked every day to make dairy products, which will be sold at the local markets. This will increase the family income and help them to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow.

loans.name: Elgine

texts.en:
Elgine is 28 years old and married. She has three children, two of whom are in school.

Elgine is in the agricultural business raising livestock in the Philippines. Elgine requested a 23,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional livestocks to raise.

Elgine has been raising livestocks for three years now and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Elgine would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock to raise.

loans.name: Mwambiro

texts.en:
Mwambiro, aged 26 years, is a married woman with three children all under her care. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and clothing. 

Mwambiro operates a vegetable and fruit selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit vending business in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason with the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons and pawpaws. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons and pawpaws.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is a man of twenty-five years, married to Lydia and a father of one lovely child. He sells CDs and also has a food kiosk. He has been in this business for six years now and gets a monthly income of 40,000 shillings.

This will be Wilson's first loan with KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to buy CDs to sell, and also a machine that is used to play the CDs. 

In the future, he wants to own a CD-making company and also employ more people to work for him.

loans.use: to purchase CDs and a machine to play the CDs.

loans.name: Nelfa

texts.en:
Nelfa is 55 years old and married with four children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Nelfa runs an electrical supplies business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional electrical supplies to sell.

Nelfa has been in this business for eight years.

In the future, Nelfa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional electrical supplies to sell.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a man of 34 years. He is married to Pauline and is a father of three children. He runs a taxi business in Kangemi and has been in this business for five years now. He gets a monthly income of 35,000 Kenyan shillings.

This will be Paul's second loan with KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to buy taxi accessories and also take the taxi for full service. In the future, he wants to educate his children.

loans.use: To pay for car service and buy car accesories.

loans.name: Beka

texts.en:
Beka is 22 years old. He lives in the capital city of Georgia, Tbilisi, with his 22-year-old wife, his children and his mother. The two children are ages six months and four years. Beka requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the monthly pension of Beka’s wife. She has health problems and is getting social help from government institutions.
 
Recently, Beka requested a loan from Credo, to start up a family business. Beka has now been approved for a loan, within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up Loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits, with soft conditions, to rural poor people who do not have access to other credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income.

With his credit, Beka will open a plumbing shop. He already has a commercial space where he plans to open the shop. Beka will purchase plumbing materials at low cost and sell them, with a price markup, from his shop. He is planning to work as the seller himself, in order to decrease expenses. Beka is a very hard-working man, and he will try his best to make a good profit from his business. He wants to look after his family better and provide them with everything they need for living.

loans.use: To open a shop selling plumbing supplies

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes, aged 38 years, is married and has two kids. The children are 14 and 17 years old. The family lives at their own house, which has electricity and piped water. Agnes's greatest monthly expenses are food and rental bills. 

She has owned rental houses for the past five years, and her customers are tenants and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of a lack of capital to expand her business. She dreams of establishing more rental houses in the future.

With the loan she is requesting, KES 50,000, she wants to expand her business. To do so, she will buy cement, blocks and sand. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy cement, blocks and sand for building more rental houses.

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.en:
Maimuna,aged 30, is a married woman with two kids who attend school. She lives at her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over a year, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Maimuna dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of 10,000 KES, she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans.

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en: Rosenda is a married woman and has four children from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in a fishing business together with her husband for more than six years now. This is the source of their income. Rosenda is asking for a loan to buy materials for fishing like nets, lead weights, nylon, and others. This loan would be a great help in improving their fishing venture. Rosenda hopes to make their business a stable source of income. She also dreams of sending her children to school and becoming successful professional in the future.

loans.use: to buy materials for fishing like nets, lead weights, nylon, and others.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga is 49 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Dominga is borrowing 25,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional feeds for her pigs.

Dominga has been raising pigs for 12 years and also earns additional income from a general store and retail of gasoline.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her raising pigs, general store, and retail of gasoline businesses.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional feeds for her pigs.

loans.name: Ivane

texts.en:
Ivane is 59 years old. He lives in the Akhaltsikhe district with his 53-year-old wife, Mzia, and two children. 

Ivane requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is Mzia’s monthly salary. She is working at the local restaurant as a waitress. The small salary that she earns is not even enough for food for the family. 

Ivane requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Ivane will purchase raw materials for his cement workshop. He will start producing cement blocks and sell them to the resellers at a good price to earn additional income for the family. 

 Ivane will have a new family business and will work hard to make it profitable. He will be reinvesting part of the profit in the same field, and another part will be used to improve the family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for his cement workshop.

loans.name: Josa

texts.en:
Josa is 30 years old and has three children. Josa is married and has two children who are in school.

Josa is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Josa requested a 16,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy vaccines, vitamins and other supplies for her livestock.

Josa has been raising livestock for four years now, and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain the business.

In the future, Josa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy vaccines, vitamins and other supplies for her livestock.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia has been engaged in a fishing business together with her husband for more than 13 years. She works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of their family, especially the schooling of their children. Virginia is applying for a loan to buy a new boat engine and fishing nets. With these items her husband will be able to increase his catch, allowing them to sell more fish in the market. In the future, Virginia hopes to make their venture a success.

loans.use: to buy a new boat engine and fishing nets.

loans.name: Al-Raja Group

texts.en: Al-Raja group consists of four ladies Arzag, Saly, Raja, and Rina who live in Aden, Yemen. They are hardworking women who strive to increase their profit. Raja is 44 years old and is the president of the group. She is a married woman and has six children. She has been selling perfumes, clothes, and other items in order to provide for her family. She is continually doing her best to grow her business well. So, she applied for a second loan of 100,000 YER from AMB to buy  ladies' clothes and perfumes to be able to continue her business. All members of this group thank Kiva lenders for funding them the first loan, and they hope also to be funded in this loan.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes, incense, and ladies' clothes such as pants, blouses, and skirts.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa earns a living through her convenience or sari-sari store. She lives with her family in Bohol, Philippines. Theresa has been engaged in this business for more than 10 years now. Theresa is asking for a loan to buy more stocks for her store like canned goods, candies, soap, toiletries, and others. Through this, she will be able to improve her business a makes more successful and more productive.

loans.use: to buy more stocks for her store like canned goods, candies, soap, toiletries, and others.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

Rosalia has been in this business for five years. Rosalia also earns income from raising livestock.

Rosalia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Vita

texts.en:
Vita is a farmer from the town of Ubay, Bohol. She is a married woman and has four children. 

She has been in the farming business for more than ten years now. This is the source of their income. 

Vita is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer, pesticides and sacks. Through this, she will be able to improve her farm as well as her harvest. 

In the future, Vita hopes to make her business a sustainable and successful one.

loans.use: to to buy seedlings, fertilizer, pesticides and sacks.

loans.name: Juntos Por El Progreso Group

texts.es:
La socia pertenece  al banco comunal JUNTOS PARA EL PROGRESO; este banco está situado en el distrito de  Wanchaq en la provincia  de Cusco departamento de Cusco.
La socia Veronica tiene 41 años de edad ,02 hijos y es soltera, la socia  alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de productos de belleza como colonias, perfumes, cremas entre otros, la socia vende de forma ambulatoria a sus amistades y familiares, que le solicitan, la socia lleva años en este negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa siendo de esta forma que la socia saca adelante  a su familia.
La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercadería como perfumes para damas.
Los otros socios se dedican a la venta de maestro contratista, venta de golosinas, venta de ropa, plastiqueria, venta de verdura, venta de artefactos, venta de cds.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete  a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
Veronica belongs to the communal bank, Juntos Para el Progreso. This bank is located in the district of Wanchaq, in the province and region of Cusco. Veronica is 41 years old, and she is the single mother of two children. She works each day at her business selling beauty products such as colognes, perfumes, creams, and other items. She sells her wares as a street vendor to her friends and family, who request her. She has done this work for years, which is going well thanks to the commitment she puts into her business each day. She is a responsible and committed person, and this is her way of getting her family ahead. 

Veronica is requesting this loan in order to purchase merchandise such as women's perfumes. The other members work as contractors, selling candies, clothing, plastics, vegetables, curios, and compact discs. This member is grateful for the approved loan and promises to make her schedule payments.

loans.use: purchase merchandise such as ladies perfumes.

loans.name: Adam

texts.en:
Adam is 30 years old. He lives in a small village near the capital city of Georgia with his parents and sister. Adam requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for his family's business start-up but without any success. His loan requests were rejected because of his low income and his family’s poor living conditions. 

Adam’s sister works as a teacher at a local school and his mother works as a baker, each generating a small monthly income. Adam has a tractor which he rents out as well. However, their incomes are hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations, the family is categorized as subsistence poor. 

Adam requested a loan from Credo to start a family business. Adam has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages providing business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With his credit Adam will pay a toll for another tractor. After the toll is paid, he will renovate it and rent it out to increase the income of his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to pay the toll for a tractor.

loans.name: Mechell

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Mechell works hard to support her family.

She buys and sells vegetables in the Philippines and also earns income from raising livestock. Mechell is borrowing PHP 24000 through NWTF to purchase additional vegetables to sell.

Mechell has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Flor De Fatima

texts.es: Doña Flor, habitante del barrio laureles sur, con su esposo se apoya para sufragar los gastos diarios del hogar como la alimentación, cargos básicos de agua luz, tienen dos hijos a su cargo quienes estudian y desean salir adelante con sus estudios y doña Flor con sus pocos ingresos como docente da lo ultimo para apoyarles. El crédito que solicita es para empezar a construir el muro perimetral de su vivienda lo cual es necesario por la alta delincuencia en su zona y con esta construcción se sentirá más segura.
texts.en: Flor lives in the Laureles Sur neighborhood with her husband. She helps to cover daily household expenses such as food and basic utilities such as water and electricity. She cares for two children who are in school and hope to continue getting ahead with their studies. Flor, with her meager teacher's salary, puts everything toward helping her children. The loan she is requesting will go toward beginning construction on the perimeter wall of the household, which is necessary due to the high levels of crime in her neighborhood. With this construction she will feel much safer.

loans.use: purchase cement, sand, iron, blocks, and gravel.

loans.name: Survey Group

texts.en:
Virginia is in her early 50's and is married with six children.  Three of her children are grown-ups and the other three are still at school.  She has been running a grocery store since 1981.  She works from 7.00 am to 11.00 pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Virginia's 12th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans, which she has paid back successfully, to buy more beers, sodas, juice and water.  She used the profit to pay school fees and cover household expenses. She will use this loan to restock the missing drinks and to buy a deep freezer to sell more cold drinks.

Virginia will share this loan with her seven member loan group "survey" who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy a deep freezer to sell more cold drinks and to buy additional drinks.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is 29 years old, married, and has four school-going children. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a food stall business from her home, selling household consumables such as wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition in her business.  Her dream is to establish a wholesale business in the near future. 

With the KES 50,000 loan she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and rice.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is 41 years old, is married and has three children.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Vilma is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to purchase additional feed and livestock to raise.

Vilma has been raising livestock for five years and also earns income from selling herbal medicines and vinegar.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and livestock to raise.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is 26 years old and is married. She lives with her husband, Bakari, at their house that lacks both electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Mwanasha has operated a firewood and charcoal selling business for the past two years. She sells from their home to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is stiff competition.

With the loan of KES 30,000, she wants to purchase stock of firewood and charcoal to sell. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase stock of firewood and charcoal to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 26 years old, married to Agnes and a father of four children. He sells movies, DVDs and music CDs in Kangemi and has been in this business for five years now. He earns a monthly income of twenty five thousand shillings.

This will be John's first loan with KADET LTD and he plans to use the entire loan to buy CDs and DVDs to sell. In the future he wants to educate his children to higher levels.

loans.use: to buy CDs and DVDs to sell

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana is 21 years old. She lives in the Rustavi district of Georgia with her parents, sister and retired grandfather.  Ana requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but did not have any success. Her loan request was rejected because of her low income and her family’s poor living conditions. 

Ana is a teacher of Microsoft Office programs. She is giving private lessons and earns a small monthly salary. Her father is working on a mini bus-line and her sister is video operator. Their family also receives additional income from Ana’s grandfather’s monthly pension.

Ana requested a loan from Credo to start-up a business. Ana has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low incomes. With her credit Ana will rent a commercial space and purchase all the needed equipment to open a Microsoft Office learning center. As Ana will have a bigger space and more computers she will be able to give group lessons and have more students. She is already well known in this field in her district, so her business will be successful. This will significantly increase her income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to rent space and open a Microsoft Office learning center.

loans.name: Silfanos

texts.en:
Silfanos is a 55-year-old, married man. He has five children, whose ages range from 16 to 28 years. He describes himself as ambitious. He operates a tailoring business, where he makes clothing to sell. He has been involved in this business for 20 years. His business is located in an area with many customers, and his primary customers are both individuals and companies. He says that his biggest business challenge is a lack of enough capital.

He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more sewing machines, to use in tailoring. His business goal is to have a larger market share, within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will improve his standard of living. This is Silfanos's second loan with SMEP DTM. He repaid his previous loan successfully.

loans.use: to buy more sewing machines for his tailoring business

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu, aged 47, is a widow. She is the mother of three kids, all of whom graduated from school. She lives at her own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over 10 years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Saumu dreams of establishing a restaurant business, in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting, in the amount of KES 40,000, she wants to purchase a stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of wheat flour, maize flour, and beans.

loans.name: Merab

texts.en:
Merab is 28 years old and lives in Tsalka District with his wife and three children. He works as a mechanic at an auto repair shop. The family has a plot of land where they grow potatoes and then sell them at local markets. But the money Merab earns is hardly enough to pay for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Merab requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up but without any success. His loan request was rejected every time because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions.

Merab then requested a 3000 USD start-up loan from Credo. His request was approved within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This start-up loan program envisions providing start-up and re-startup loans with easy terms to country rural poor who do not have access to credit products, as they are regarded as high-risk borrowers due to low incomes.

With his loan Merab will open an auto parts shop. As he is well known locally and has a good number of clients, he thinks that the business will be profitable. This new business initiative financed with a Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of Merab’s family.

loans.use: to open an auto parts shop.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna is a 51 years old and is married. She has four children and lives in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Lorna owns and manages transportation services for a living and has been in this business for four years. She earns 10,000 from this business monthly. She requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase tires and accesories for better services. Lorna joined GDMPC this year. In the future, Lorna hopes to enable her children to finish their studies and to double her income from her business.

loans.use: to purchase tires and accesories.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa is 51 years old, is married and has nine children, four of whom are in school.

Josefa raises hogs in the Philippines. Josefa requested a PHP 11000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Josefa has raised hogs for 10 years now and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Josefa would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a 42-year-old married woman. She has seven children ranging from 3 years old to 24 years old. She describes herself as ambitious and determined. She operates rental houses and also sells cereals to supplement her income. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in an area with many customers and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be water and transportation for clients. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to renovate houses and purchase more maize to sell. Her business goal is to have a restaurant within 5 years. She hopes she will have a stable business in the future. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to renovate rental houses and purchase maize to sell.

loans.name: Eliver

texts.en:
Eliver is a 36-year-old mother from Migosi estate in Kisumu city, which is found in the western part of Kenya. She supports five people in her family. She is married to John, who is a business man. She has four children, who are 13, 10, 5 and 3 years old.

She has a grocery stall, which she has been operating for the past 10 years. She earns a monthly income of KES 36,000. Eliver has applied for her fifth loan with KADET LTD. She will use the loan to purchase vegetables in large quantity to resell. She will use the anticipated profit to plow back into the business. Her dream is to expand the current business, and to be able to provide for her family's needs.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Marylyn

texts.en:
Marylyn is married, 44 years old, and supports a family of eight. Her children are aged between 21 and three years old. She sells stationery in Kabarnet and has been in operation for a period of three years, earning an income of KES. 20,000.

She has asked for a second loan of KES 70,000 with KADET LTD and wishes to use this amount to purchase more stationery to sell.  

The anticipated amounts earned will be put back into her business. Her dream is to own a wholesale shop and live happily.

loans.use: to purchase more stationery to sell

loans.name: Lindi Group

texts.en:
Amina, who is in her early 30s, is a married woman with three children who are in school. For three years now she has been selling tie and dye clothes up country (this fabric is commonly known as batiki in Tanzania). She works from 10 am to 7 pm if she is in her trading center but normally she travels up country for business. She is able to make a small profit per month. 

This will be her fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. The previous loans, all of which she has paid back successfully, she used to add more rolls of material for her tie and dye.  She started by buying ten meters and now she can buy two rolls, which is a great improvement. She is really doing great and is happy with the loans.  She used the profit she earned to start building her own house.  She will use this loan to buy two rolls of material for making more tie and die pieces.  She is dreaming of finishing her house.

Amina will share this loan with her ten member loan group "Lindi" who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy two rolls of material for making more tie and die pieces.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is 29 years old, married to Christine and the father of one child. He is a charcoal dealer and also provides motorcycle transportation. He has been in this business for four years now and earns monthly income of 35,000 shillings.

This will be Nicholas's second loan with KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to buy another motorcycle. In the future he wants to educate his child and start a taxi business.

loans.use: to purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed is taking out another Kiva loan of KES 40,000 to boost his business. He is grateful for the opportunity given by Kiva lenders and Yehu Microfinance to improve his business and his family's standard of living. With the loan, he wants to purchase colored paints to paint his rental house.

loans.use: to purchase color paints for his rental house.

loans.name: Edith

texts.es:
Edith tiene 31 años de edad y esta casada con Rubén con quien tiene una hija de 10 años respectivamente . juntos viven en su casa construida a base de material noble.Desde muy joven su principal sustento económico fue la producción de cacao orgánico donde gracias a su esposo logro adquirir un terreno agrícola de 5 hectáreas para continuar de manera independiente con la cosecha de este producto rentable.Es una labor que desempeña gracias a sus padres porque desde niña los ayudo en tareas menores correspondiente a este producto cuya demanda es muy buena.Al iniciarse el principal inconveniente que tuvo fue de no contar con un capital suficiente para la compra de un terreno para obtener un ingreso líquido obligada a alquilar terrenos de cultivo pero con el paso de los años y trabajando en ocasiones mas de lo necesario pudo comprarse sus propios terrenos.
Para obtener una calidad comercial de sus producción debe aplicar abono orgánico, asimismo para acortar las demás tareas contrata a trabajadores del lugar para tareas como el retiro de mala hierba y cosecha de mazorcas siendo necesario contar con un  capital de trabajo para el pago respectivo de su personal de manera anticipada siendo su principal inconveniente en muchas ocasiones.Este es su primer crédito otorgado por Kiva,  esta agradecida por la oportunidad y espera usar de manera inteligente el dinero  otorgado.Desea contar con 2,000 nuevos soles y contratar trabajadores del lugar para cultivar sus terrenos agrícolas.
texts.en:
Edith is 31 years old and is married to Ruben, with whom she has one daughter who is 10 years old. They live together in their house, made of good materials. Since she was very young, her economic sustenance has been raising organic cacao. Thanks to her husband, she acquired an agricultural plot of land that is five hectares in order to continue to independently harvest this profitable product. This is work that she does thanks to her parents, because since she was a girl, she helped them with small chores related to farming this product, for which demand is very good. At the beginning, the main inconvenience was that she did not have enough working capital to purchase a plot of land in order to have liquid income, so she had to rent farm land, but with the passing of the years and working more often than necessary, she was able to buy herself her own land.

To have commercial-quality production, she should put down organic fertilizer, and to cut down on the work she has to do, she should contract with laborers in the area to do work such as pull weeds and raise corn, so it is necessary to have working capital to pay for her staff as expected, which has been her main difficulty on many occasions. This is her first loan through Kiva. She is grateful for the opportunity and hopes to use the money intelligently. She would like to have 2,000 nuevos soles and contract with laborers in the area to cultivate her farmland.

loans.use: to contract with workers from the area.

loans.name: Corazon De Jesus Cristal Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “CORAZON DE JESUS CRISTAL” iniciará el quinto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Senkata, está compuesta por doce  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Isabel es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de productos varios, venta de comida, venta de ropa interior, venta de cosméticos, costura de deportivos, venta de mantas, venta de flores, costura y venta de polleras, constructora, venta de pollos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Isabel es integrante, ella indica que hace dos años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tejido y venta de mantas; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió por un capital en lana que tenía y decidió producirlo y comercializarlo.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de lana) que adquirirá de las ferias de la Ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella vive en unión libre y tiene seis hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The “CORAZON DE JESUS CRISTAL" communal bank is beginning its fifth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Senkata center.  It's made up of twelve ladies and directed by a board of directors where Isabel serves as the president.  The members have various types of businesses, including food sales, undergarment sales, cosmetic sales, sport clothing manufacture, blankets, flowers, sewing, t-shirts, building and chicken sales.

This loan will benefit their small businesses including Isabela's.  She says that it's been two years since she joined Pro Mujer, having joined on the invitation of a promoter who visited her in her home.  She currently has a blanket knitting business and says that she started this business with some yarn that she had and she decided to produce and sell it.

She will use the money from this loan to buy yarn at the fairs in El Alto and then sell the things she makes at her stall.  This type of work allows her to generate some income to support her household because she is in a common law marriage and has six children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says that she likes the health care and loans.

loans.use: to buy yarn.

loans.name: Rosa Miriam

texts.es: Rosa de 55 años de edad, vive con su familia en casa propia, ella se dedica a comprar cerdos tiernos los cuales cría y posteriormente comercializa. El negocio esta ubicado en su lugar de residencia por lo que cuenta con un lugar muy apto para este tipo de trabajo, Rosa es una persona muy responsable y trabajadora quien ha sacado adelante a su familia, desde hace varios años se dedica a este trabajo, ella desea contar con mayor cantidad de cerdos para extender aún más su negocio, es por eso que solicita un credito por medio del cual pueda invertir en la compra de concentrado para cerdos, vitaminas y mejorar el lugar en el cual habitan las crias asi como muestra la fotografia y así brindar un mejor servicio, el cual le permita mejorar sus ganancias y darle a su familia un mejor estabilidad economica.
texts.en: Rosa  is 55 years old and lives with her family in a home of her own.  She buys piglets, raises them and sells them.  Her business is located in her home, where she has an appropriate area for this.  Rosa is a very responsible, hardworking person who has gotten her family ahead.  She has been doing this for several years and wants to have many pigs so she can grow her business.  She is asking for a loan so she can buy feed, vitamins, and improve the area where she raises her pigs, as shown in the photograph, and provide better service.  This will allow her to improve her income and provide her family with better financial stability.

loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
Gerardo se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno para la producción de leche la cual vende a una de las Plantas Industrializadoras de Leche. El vive con  uno de sus hijos el cual ya tiene su respectiva familia, en su casa propia ubicada en la comunidad de Sullcataca Baja, del Sector Laja de La provincia Los Andes del Departamento de La Paz a una hora de distancia  de la ciudad de La Paz

El crédito lo requiere para comprar una parte de maquinaria (Rastra) que le es de mucha necesidad para mejorar su  trabajo con su tractor en el sembradío de forraje, puesto que  la rastra que tiene actualmente se encuentra oxidado y en mal estado, dañando  la  composición del suelo por lo tanto baja el rendimiento en la producción del forraje 
.
El sueño de Gerardo es incrementar mas sus cabezas de ganado por lo tanto su  producción de leche.

Es la tercera vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la segunda vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Gerardo raises cows to produce milk, which he sells to one of the Industrial Milk Plants. He lives with one of his sons who has a family of his own in his own home located in the community of Sullcataca Baja, in the Laja sector in the province of Los Andes in the department of La Paz, which is one hour away from the city of La Paz.

He needs the loan to purchase a piece of machinery (a rake) that is very much needed to improve his work with his tractor in planting fodder because the rake that he currently has is rusted and in bad shape, hurting the ground and reducing the amount of fodder that can be produced.

Gerardo's dream is to increase the number of heads of cattle he has, as well as his milk production.

This is the third time he has taken out a loan with IMPRO and the second time with Kiva.

loans.use: purchase a rake, which is part of the tractor that he uses to plant fodder for his milk cows.

loans.name: Clarissa

texts.en:
Clarissa is a 41-year-old, married woman who has three children. She lives at Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Clarissa has been working at her gardening business for seven years. She meets her family's needs from the little amount (4,000) she earns monthly from her gardening business.

However, in 2012 Clarissa joined GDMPC. Now she has applied for a loan from GDMPC Microfinance, in the amount of 30,000 PHP. She will use the loan to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Clarissa wants to make an expansion to her business, one day.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to maintain his crops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Pikria

texts.en:
Pikria is 31 years old. She lives in Ikalto village, Telavi district, with her 32-year-old husband, Besik, and her retired mother-in-law. Pikria requested a loan from local financial institutions several times, for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions.

Pikria and her husband are working, receiving small monthly salaries. She is an accountant at the local factory, and Besik is an artisan and works on house renovations for private orders. The family also runs an agricultural business. In particular, they have a vineyard and a milk cow. The cow is milked every day to make dairy products, and these are sold with the harvested grapes, at local markets. The family receives some additional income -- specifically, Pikria’s mother-in-law’s monthly pension.

Pikria requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Pikria has now been approved for a loan, within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up Loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits, with soft conditions, to rural poor people who do not have access to other credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income.

With her credit, Pikria will purchase a truck. Her husband will be driving the truck and transporting cargo on private orders. This will help them to earn additional income for the family. The profit will be used for expanding the agricultural business. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up Loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To buy a truck and start up a cargo transportation business

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
This is Titus. He previously accessed a 16,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that he used to buy spare parts and accessories and pay for the maintenance of their Jeepney unit. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in his personal, household and business expenditures.

He would like to apply for a new 30,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and pay for the maintenance of the Jeepney unit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain their daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Titus hopes to buy another Jeepney and dreams that his children will finish their studies. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week, and this is where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of the Jeepney unit.

loans.name: Ivania

texts.es:
La  Joven  Ivania de 21 años de edad  vive con su esposo y su hijo de 3 años de edad en su casa de habitación, se dedica  ala venta de ropa americana  como ser,  pantalones para caballeros y niños blusas para damas, trajes de niños, vestidos para niñas y toda una gran variedad en ropa de vestir.
Ivania su negocio está ubicado en su casa de habitación donde le visitan todas las personas de su barrio quienes son sus clientes, aparte de vender en su casa también viaja al salvador donde tiene clientes que les da producto al crédito, además de dar  crédito aprovecha para comprar fragancias para damas y caballeros en ese país.
Ivania se dedica a esta actividad desde hace un año sus ventas son de lunes a sábado su negocio está ubicado  en el municipio de San Lorenzo valle, al sur de Honduras.
Ivania está solicitando el préstamo para compra de  fardos de ropa americana como ser pantalones, vestidos, blusas, camisas, calzonetas, etc. Y Con las ganancias y el apoyo de este préstamo desea salir adelante y seguir mejorando su negocio.
Vania su sueño es  crecer más en su negocio y en clientes.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Abril  del 2013.
texts.en:
Ivania is 21 years old and lives with her husband and three year old son.  She sells American clothing such as men's and boys' pants, blouses for women, girls' dresses and a great variety of clothing.

Ivania's business is located in her home, where people from the neighborhood visit her and are her customers.  Besides selling from her home, she also travels to El Salvador where she has customers to whom she sells on credit.  She also takes advantage of this and buys fragrances for men and women in that country.

Ivania has been doing this for a year and she sells Monday through Saturday.  She is in San Lorenzo Valley in southern Honduras.

Ivania is asking for this loan so she can buy bundles of American clothing, such as pants, dresses, shirts, undergarments, etc.  Ivania's dream is to grow her business and customer base.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools.

loans.name: Fraternidad De Urubamba Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “FRATERNIDAD DE URUBAMBA”; Este banco se ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Celedonia ella es soltera tiene 43 años; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de desayunos como quinua con leche, café, leche, kinua con manzana entre otros, la socia trabaja con su negocio hace varios años atrás el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia vende de forma ambulatoria en una de las calles de Urubamba, siendo de esta forma que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de insumos como azúcar, quinua, leche entre otros.
Los otros socios  se dedican al negocio de venta de frutas, venta de chicha, restaurante, venta de verduras, venta de desayunos.
La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members belong to the Brotherhood of Urubamba communal bank. This bank is located in the district of Urubamba, part of the province of Urubamba and the department of Cusco.

The member is Celedonia. She is 43 years old. The member mixes her daily activities with the business of selling breakfasts such as quinoa with milk, coffee, milk, quinoa with apples, etc. She has worked in this line of business for many years, which has gone well thanks to the effort she puts forth every day. She travels one of the streets of Urubamba, making her sales, as this is the way that she succeeds for her family.

The member is requesting a loan to purchase ingredients such as sugar, quinoa, milk, etc.

The other members have businesses selling fruits, selling corn drink (chicha), running a restaurant, selling vegetables, and selling breakfasts.

The member is grateful to those who are part of this dream in this way, and she promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: purchase ingredients such as sugar, quinoa, milk, etc.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a single man. He describes himself as an achiever. He operates a transport business, transporting passengers using his bicycle. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in an area with many customers, and his customers are primarily locals. He says his biggest business challenge is harsh weather conditions.

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy another bicycle. His business goal is to have a motorcycle within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be wealthy. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy another bicycle

loans.name: Mamuka

texts.en:
Mamuka is 24 years old. He lives in a small village of Kobuleti District, with his mother. Mamuka requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Mamuka has a 0.5-hectare plot of agricultural land, where vegetables and citrus are grown. He sells the harvested products at local markets. Mamuka’s mother works as a cook at a local restaurant, and gets monthly income. They earn hardly enough to have food for the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Mamuka requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Mamuka has now been approved for a loan, within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits, with soft conditions, to rural poor people who do not have access to other credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income.

With his credit, Mamuka will open a local grocery store. This will increase the income of the family. Part of the new income will be reinvested in the same business, and they will use another part to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to open a grocery store

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is a 32-year-old spare parts dealer, in Bombolulu-Kisimani, Mombasa. He is a married father of two children. He has been in this business for the past three years and has done well.

This loan marks his second borrowing from KADET LTD to finance his business. He will use the loan to purchase a stock of electronic spare parts, and motorcycle spare parts for his shop. The anticipated profit will help him service his loan and expand his shop. He hopes to have a better life with his family, in future.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of electronic spare parts, and motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Zaza

texts.en:
Zaza is 30 years old. He lives in Sagarejo District with his 27-year-old wife, Lela, his parents and his brother. Zaza requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions.
 
The main source of the income for the family is from poultry. They have chickens and sell eggs at the local markets.

Zaza requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Zaza has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Zaza will renovate the commercial space and purchase grocery stock to open a grocery shop. As he owns the space and will not have to pay the rent for it, Zaza will have a good profit. In order to decrease the expenses, he and his wife will be working in the shop as sellers. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To open a grocery shop.

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
This is Edwin. His previous loan was really a great help for his food stall as well as his landscaping projects. The loan also helped with their household's expenditures as well as with his children's education. He and his wife are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs. 

He would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan for him to buy raw ingredients such as rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and other products needed for his business. He will also use the loan for his landscaping projects. Profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of one of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Edwin hopes that his business will continue to be successful and dreams that his business will continue to flourish. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of his life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients such as rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and other products needed for his business.

loans.name: Newen Tragün Group

texts.es: Zunilda, quien está ubicada al extremo derecho agachada con una blusa blanca y un morral verde con café, es una aguerrida mujer que participa en el Banco Comunal de Villarrica, llamado Newen Tragün. En este Banco Comunal hay variados negocios entre los cuales destacan socios que tiene una ruca, (vivienda tradicional de mapuches), artesanías  en lana y cuero, masajistas, turismo, proyectistas, jardineros, y venta de comidas en carros ambulantes. Zunilda, quien es nuestra entrevistada, nos cuenta que ella tiene un carrito de venta de comida, además de vender artesanías, nos cuenta que su negocio lo empezó hace 11 años aproximadamente, y que todo lo aprendió de su cultura, la mapuche; siempre en su vida estuvo presente el tejer a telar, hacer artesanías y cocinar comidas típicas además de tener un fogón en donde se preocupa de rescatar la artesanía típica de Chile, y también imparte cursos gratis para quienes quieren aprenderla.  Ha tenido muchos problemas para poder salir adelante, ya que en el camino ha perdido a su madre, su esposo y su hijo, además de quedarse sola cuidando sus tierras, ya que sus hermanos decidieron irse a vivir a la ciudad, buscando más trabajo y a ella la abandonaron, por lo cual ella ha debido trabajar sola, y cuidar sola de sus tierras, además de no contar con el agua necesaria, ya que en donde ella vive no existe el agua por cañerías, solo hay que ir a buscarla a lagos o sacarla de pozos, es por esto que su negocio se ha visto afectado. Debido a esto, ella debe dejar sus terrenos e irse a vivir a otras tierras. Con el crédito que obtendrá, podrá comprar más insumos para su negocio, como por ejemplo lana, insumos para dar sus cursos gratis. Espera que le vaya muy bien en su negocio a pesar de que deba cambiarse de lugar, sabe que podría irle muy bien.  Le ha gustado mucho trabajar junto a Fondo Esperanza por los requisitos que solicitan y la responsabilidad con la que se trabaja.
texts.en:
Zunilda, who is on the far right of the photo, dressed in a white blouse and holding a green and brown bag, is a courageous woman who participates in the communal bank of Villarrica named Newn Tragun. In this communal bank, there is a variety of businesses. Members who stand out include those who have a ruca (a traditional home of the Mapuches), artists who work in wool and leather, massage therapists, those who work in tourism, designers, gardeners, and those who sell food out of street carts.

Zunilda, who is our interviewee, tells us that she has a little food cart, and she also sells handicrafts. She tells us that she started her business approximately 11 years ago, and that she learned everything from her culture, the mapuche culture. There was always present in her life crocheting, weaving, making handicrafts, and cooking typical foods, as well as having a stove where she brought to life the meals of Chile. She also teaches free classes to those who want to learn the trade. She has had many problems getting ahead because on the way she has lost her mother, her husband, and her son. In addition to being alone caring for her land, her siblings decided to leave to live in the city, looking for more work, and they abandoned her. This is why she has had to work alone and care for her land alone. Also, she has not had the water she needs because where she lives there is not plumbing for water. The only thing to do is go look for it in the lakes or take it out of wells. This is why her business has been affected. Because of this, she has to leave her land and go live somewhere else. With the loan that she will receive, she will be able to buy more supplies for her business such as wool and supplies to teach her classes for free. She hopes that things will go very well for her business even though she has to relocate. She knows that it could go very well for her. She has greatly enjoyed working with Kiva partner Fondo Esperanza for the loans she has requested and the responsibility of working with them.

**Translator's note: The advertisement in the background of the photo says "To know that you help me, for me is a miracle."

loans.use: purchase wool and supplies for her classes

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 33-year-old Gloria from Torkpoi town Bo. She is married with 2 children between the ages of 8 and 12. Her children are attending school. She began her business because she wants to engage herself and become useful to her family.

Gloria runs a tailoring shop; she sells female and male clothing and traditional pattern design clothing. She has been running this business for 5 years. She works at the business every day, 12 hours per day. She says that the main challenge for her business is insufficient financing to prepare different types of clothing for resale.

Gloria has requested a loan in order to purchase more clothing material. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and improve her business. In the future, she plans to own a permanent tailoring structure. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase more clothing material.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en: Sylvia a 45-year-old married woman with 3 children living in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She was able to provide for the needs of her children from her 4,000 monthly earnings from the business for 10 years. Her business is an aid to the income her husband earns from fishing and farming. In 2008, Sylvia joined GDMPC, and she is applying for a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure for farm maintenance. She wants to expand her farming business one day.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure for farm maintenance

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en: Roselyn is a married woman. She has 3 children with ages ranging from 12 to 20 years. She describes herself as ambitious. She operates a dry cleaning business where she cleans clothes for customers. She has been involved in this business for 7 years. Her business is located in an area with many customers and her primary customers are locals. She describes lack of sufficient capital as her biggest business challenge. She will use the 50,000 KES loan to to buy detergents for cleaning clothes. Her business goal is to expand her business within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, this will improve her living standards. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan was paid successfully.

loans.use: to buy detergents for cleaning clothes.

loans.name: Obey Chamananzva Group

texts.en: Greetings from Masvingo, Zimbabwe! This is 64-year-old Egnes. She is widowed and has seven children. Egnes runs a poultry business. The business has been in operation for two years. She says the main challenge she faces is the premature death of chicks due to diseases, thereby affecting the profitability of her business. Egnes has requested a loan of $300 to buy chicks and feeds. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will go towards her family's upkeep. In the future, Egnes plans to expand her business and be able to keep more than 1,000 chicks at a time.

loans.use: to buy chicks and feeds.

loans.name: Mandivengereyi

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 46-year-old Mandivengereyi, from Harare. She is married, with four children.  

Mandivengereyi runs a tailoring business where she makes curtains, throw-overs, and seat covers. The business has been in operation for two years. She says the main challenge she encounters is a lack of capital to buy adequate materials for her orders. 

Mandivengereyi has requested for a loan of USD 500 to buy materials and threads. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will increase her household income, enabling her to provide a better quality life for her family. 

In the future, Mandivengereyi plans to grow her business and open a big shop.

loans.use: to buy sewing materials & threads for her business.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is married and has 10 children. He has received a middle school education and his wife is a trained teacher.

Michael owns and operates a drinking spot located in Likpe Bakua in the Hohoe community. He has been operating this drinking spot for the past 12 years to support himself and his family, since he is responsible for all the financial needs of his family.

Michael will use this loan to buy cartons of soft drinks, biscuits and pastries. He hopes to use the new profits from his expanded business to save towards his old age.

loans.use: to buy cartons of soft drinks, biscuits and pastries.

loans.name: Sorie

texts.en: Salone Microfinance Trust, a partner of Kiva.org based in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you Sorie, a staff member at one of the sugar-producing companies in Sierra Leone. He has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 2,800,000. With the help of this loan, he can buy house-building materials like iron corrugated sheets, cements, iron rods, etc. for the construction of a dwelling house for his family. Sorie is a native of the Magbass village. He is 33 years of age. He is married to a businesswoman and the couple has two children who are attending primary school.

loans.use: to buy house building materials like iron corrugated sheets, cements, iron rods, etc.

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en: Cornelia is a petty trader Likpe Bakua, Hohoe. Cornelia has never received any formal education.  She is married and has 8 children. Her husband is into peasant farming. Cornelia has been dealing in all sort of petty business for survival for the past 10years. She assists the husband with the basic needs of her family. Her loan will be used to buy bag of maize and soft drinks for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards paying their children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy bag of maize and soft drinks for sale.

loans.name: Christabell

texts.en:
Christabell is a hairdresser in Likpe Bakua, Hohoe. Christabell has received no form of formal education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a civilian. Christabell has been a hairdresser for five years now. She has been assisting her husband with the basic needs of the home. Her loan will be used to purchase different types of hair relaxers and hair extensions. 

She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and acquire a hair dryer.

loans.use: to purchase different types of hair relaxers and hair extensions.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is married and has 8 children. She has received no form of formal education. 

Veronica deals in the sales of paddy rice in Likpe Bakua, Hohoe, which she has done for the past two years. Her husband is a mason. Veronica uses her income to assist her husband in providing the basic necessities of the home. 

She will use the loan to purchase bags of paddy rice from local farmers, and resell it to market women and food vendors. 

With the new profits from her expanded business, Veronica plans to save to help her husband give their children a quality education.

loans.use: to purchase bags of paddy rice from the local farmers and resell it to market women and food vendors.

loans.name: Saiid

texts.en:
Saiid is a 27-year-old Lebanese man. He’s single and living with his parents and two siblings. His father is the one responsible for them, and the whole family is really thankful for what he did so far and will be going to do. 

Saiid decided to start his own work as a photographer in 2008 and has opened his own studio. He’s talented and works with high professionalism. Today, he’s asking for a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase a new camera for his work in order to increase his sales, and thus, his revenues. In the future, he plans to open his own photography center.

loans.use: to purchase a new camera for his work.

loans.name: Mwinyihaji

texts.en:
Mwinyihaji is a father of one kid. He owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. For the last three years, he has been running a cyber cafe, and apart from that, he does another business of hiring out tents. Theft and breakdown of machines are his major challenges.

He is requesting a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to buy spare parts to maintain his computers to avoid the breakdowns and continue with his business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to maintain his computers.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past three months, Sofia has been working hard to manage her small charcoal business, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Sofia has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to add different fruits and tomatoes to sell, and will help Sofia to generate greater profits and start selling vegetables. Sofia hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Sofia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to add different fruits and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Molatf

texts.en:
Molatf is a 34-year-old married man who lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He is the father of four children. He is employed and gets a small salary that is not enough to cover all the family's needs. He said his wife feels that it is hard to wash clothes by her hands due to the lack of money to buy a washing machine. He also needs to buy a fridge to keep foods and juices safe and cold.

He is requesting a loan of 99,999 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB to help him cover the cost of purchasing a new fridge and washing machine in order to improve the living conditions in his house. Taking this loan will allow him and his family to feel comfortable so they can enjoy living in their house.

loans.use: to cover the cost of purchasing a new fridge and washing machine in order to improve the living conditions in his house.

loans.name: Darwin

texts.en:
This is Darwin. He previously accessed a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that he utilized to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for his children's education and in his personal, household and business expenditures.

He would like to apply for a new 15,000 PHP loan that he will be utilizing to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to his inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs as well as the education of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Darwin dreams that his business will continue to flourish and that he will have more customers. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week, and this is where he can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in his business.

loans.name: Sonia Esmeralda

texts.es: sonia de 37 años de edad, vive en casa propia con su hija de 5 años de edad, Ella posee una tienda donde vende granos basicos, aceites, golosinas, entre otras cosas, tiene su negocio en el mercado que esta cerca de su lugar de residencia. sonia solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda surtir aún más la tienda con jabones, shampoos, aceites, cereales, etc de manera que pueda atender mejor a sus clientes y de esta misma forma mejorar sus ventas lo cual es su prioridad para sacar adelante su hogar.
texts.en: Sonia, 37, lives in a home of her own with her 5-year-old daughter. She owns a store that sells basic grains, oils, and candy, among other things. She has her business in the market that's close to her home. Sonia is applying for a loan through which she could further stock her store with soap, shampoo, oils, cereals, etc. in order to better attend to her customers. And in this way, she could improve her sales which is her priority for improving her home.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, oils, candy, coffee, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for more equipment and beauty products needed in her business.

loans.name: Pola

texts.en:
Pola is a married woman with five children all under her care. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She wants to start a vegetable and fruit-selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit vending business in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason with the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables, sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, water melons, and pawpaw. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes and water melons.

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en:
This is Saidi. He previously accessed a KES 30,000 loan that he added to his savings and purchased a motorcycle. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another loan of KES 30,000. With the loan he wants to purchase another motorcycle for his business to enable him cover a large geographical region. His profit from his business will definitely help him to provide for his daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in his heart.

loans.use: to purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a 25-year-old woman. She has a child who is three years old. She describes herself as focused. She operates a shoe shop where she sells sandals. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in an area with many customers and her primary customers are women and girls. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to to buy leather straps and beads to make sandals. Her business goal is to open another shop within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will export sandals to other markets in East Africa. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy straps of leather, beads and threads to make sandals.

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
Meet 29-year-old Rugiatu from Torkpoi town Bo, Southern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with children between the ages of three and nine. Two of her children are currently attending school. In 2005, Rugiatu established her palm oil business. She began her business because she wants to create a permanent source of income to support the home. She works at the business six days per week and 10 hours per day. She says that the main challenges to her business are that sometimes the purchasing power of customer is very low and market competition.

Rugiatu requires a loan in order to purchase more gallons of palm oil and beans. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and take good care of her children. In the future, Rugiatu plans to open a big palm oil store. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more gallons of palm oil and beans.

loans.name: Exson

texts.es:
Exson tiene 19 años de edad , es soltero y vive en la casa de sus padres quienes lo apoyan por ser un muchacho muy trabajador.Desde hace 1 año trabaja en un terreno agrícola que le cedieron sus padres para generar sus ingresos y mejorar su calidad de vida.Decidió trabajar en el campo porque desde niño aprendió técnicas para obtener productos de calidad como cacao orgánico y otros.Al comienzo tenía problemas económicos para comprar insumos como abono orgánico y herramientas siendo apoyado por sus padres.Todas las mañanas se dirige a su terreno ubicado a 1 hora de su localidad y retorna antes de que el sol se oculte debido a ser una zona con caminos pequeños y peligrosos.
Al finalizar la campaña de cosecha las mazorcas de cacao son secados con la luz del sol posteriormente son puestos en venta a los compradores mayoristas de su zona quienes evalúan la calidad y otorgan un precio final.
Considera su trabajo algo forzado pero también lo motiva a superarse y asi lograr sus propios objetivos.Este es su primer préstamo que Kiva y agradece la oportunidad y confianza que le brindan para lograr sus metas.Requiere 1,000 nuevos soles para comprar abono orgánico e invertir en sus cultivos .
texts.en:
Exson is 19 years old, single, and lives in his parents' home.  He supports his parents because he is a very hard-working young man.  For the past year, Exson has been working on a plot of farmland that his parents gave him so that he could make income and improve his quality of life.  He decided to work the land because he has been learning techniques for growing top-quality produce such as organic cacao since he was a young child.  At first, he experienced some financial problems in buying supplies such as organic fertilizer and tools, and he needed support from his parents.  Every morning, Exson travels to his plot of land, which is an hour away from his town, and returns home before the sun sets as he lives in an area with small, dangerous roads. 

At the end of the harvest season, Exson's cacao pods are dried in the sun and then sold to wholesalers in his region who evaluate their quality and offer him a final price.

Exson believes his work to be pretty hard but it also motivates him to improve himself and fulfill his own goals.  This is his first loan from Kiva and he is grateful for the opportunity and the trust that is being placed in him so that he can achieve his goals.  He needs 1,000 soles to buy organic fertilizer and invest in his crops.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer

loans.name: Armen

texts.en:
Armen is 28 years old. He lives in Bolnisi district with his parents. Armen requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of his low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

Armen has a grocery shop and he earns small daily income for the family. He also trades fruits and vegetables. His mother has a health problems and she is getting a monthly pension from government institutions. 

Armen requested loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Armen has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit Armen will open a car service center. He will purchase all the needed materials to build the center and also the equipment for it.
